awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Novel Photosensor Technology-Enabling the IceCube Cosmic-Neutrino Experiment (South Pole) to Open a New Window on the Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to allow for a new generation of ultrasensitive experiments on previously inaccessible scales by enabling detectors of ultrahigh energy cosmic radiation, neutrinos, dark matter and more. In addition, the technology addresses societal needs, including advancements in medical imaging and nuclear security. In the medical application, the same core technology can enable the production of cost-effective ultrasensitive whole-body-enclosing medical scanners for new preventive low-dose cancer screening of a symptom-free population. For nuclear security applications, this technology can enable widespread and cost-effective detection of illicit fissionable and radioactive materials. 

The proposed project will develop a novel particle detector, designed initially for cosmic neutrino radiation.  The extreme environment calls for changes to existing detector technology, both in terms of component design and systems engineering. Pairs of modified photosensors will need to be packed into each detector unit.  Other engineering challenges include the high-voltage supply architecture, as well as the optical path.  The entire system needs to be engineered to operate at -70 degrees C.  This project will deliver modified photosensors, additional components and interfaces, as well as conduct prototype testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For decades, the broad field of large-area photon and radiation detection has relied on a fragile and expensive pre-World-War II technology. This SBIR Project has enabled PhotonLab, Inc. to develop our novel Tandem-ABALONETM Detector technology in the field of light detection and radiation monitoring, supplanting that old technology with a modern, cost-effective and uniquely robust alternative. Moreover, PhotonLab's technology can provide new products and markets, previously considered unachievable due to the shortcomings and/or high cost of the current technologies.

Our team at PhotonLab, Inc. is pleased to announce successful completion of R&D on the Tandem-ABALONETM Detector Module, Fig. 1. A Tandem Detector comprises a pair of back-to-back oriented ABALONETM photosensors, Fig.2. We have designed, optimized, produced and successfully tested a product-level prototype. This Project has thus met all of the stated research objectives, and in certain aspects exceeded them thanks to serendipitous developments.

PhotonLab, Inc. has focused on all of the three major components of the growing $2.3 billion Market of Radiation Detection, Monitoring and Safety (per MarketsandMarkets projection for 2022):

  1. The primary focus of this SBIR Project has been to lay the technological foundations for the new generation of unprecedentedly sensitive experiments in fundamental science. These cutting-edge projects will aim to answer fundamental questions about the origins of the Universe. As the title of our SBIR Project indicates, we have initially focused our attention on a particular member within this group, the international IceCube Collaboration. The planned 'Gen-2' extension in the volume of the IceCube cosmic neutrino detector at the South Pole (from 1 km3 to about 10 km3) requires a new, cost-effective, hi-tech technology like ours. In the meantime, our success has attracted collaborators from other large-scale international projects, which plan to detect dark matter and rare nuclear decays. Members of these groups have already requested sales quotes for our products. 
  2. An official from the Department of Homeland Security has in 2018 effectively initiated the secondary effort of this SBIR Project. He proposed to employ the superior performance and cost-effectiveness of our technology in the design of a new generation of large-area radiation detectors for homeland security. This new generation of detectors should enable widespread and cost-effective monitoring of illicit fissionable and radioactive materials (a currently non-existent possibility). Our R&D within this SBIR Project has resulted in a major shift in the design, which could lead to a potentially revolutionary, uniquely robust and cost-effective solution. We will seek dedicated funding to continue this work. 
  3. The application of our core ABALONETM photosensor technology could also lead to the construction of affordable ultrasensitive whole-body-enclosing medical scanners (U.S. Patent 10,823,861) for preventive, virtually harmless (low-dose) cancer screening of symptom-free population (also a currently non-existent service). Our SBIR Project has contributed to this effort only indirectly.

Our patented (U.S. Patent 9,064,678) and proven ABALONETM photosensors can provide sensitivity to visible and ultraviolet light, exceptionally low intrinsic radioactivity and low electronic noise, along with a high overall detection performance. Moreover, for the very first time all constructional elements of a vacuum photosensor have been made of ultrapure fused quartz, with the addition of a small scintillator crystal. Metals are present only as traces of vacuum-deposited ultrathin and ultrapure films. Fused quartz is not only one of the purest and least radioactive materials, but it also transmits ultraviolet light, which is of key importance for most of our markets. Our ABALONETM photosensor technology allows utilization of fused quartz without additional costs to the assembly process compared to the usage of glass, which presents an additional unique advantage over prior art. 

The commercialization effort has thus far focused on our early adopter customers in the fundamental science research market, who are already asking us for sales quotes. Pending the initial successful implementations with current customers, we plan to broaden our commercialization approach and market our technology for use in larger markets such as medical imaging and nuclear security.

PhotonLab's publication during Phase I and II of this project:

D. Ferenc, Andrew Chang, Cameron Saylor, Sebastian Boser, Alfredo Davide Ferella, Lior Arazi, John R.Smith, Marija S. Ferenc, ABALONETM Photosensors for the IceCube experiment, NIM-A954(2020)161498.
